results.title: New weapons against crime
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin, Norton Bloom and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Demonstrates the application of modern technology to combat crime. Shows uses of computers, voice prints, olefactronics to identify odours, video tape to record crimes, electronic eavesdropping devices, and chemicals to restrain violence.

results.title: New ways with wool
results.creator_credit: Les Davidson, Australian National Film Board and Shan Benson
results.brief_description: The production of many new types of synthetic fibres is a threat to the future of the Australian wool industry - the chemist is producing new materials more closely resembling the characteristics of wool. This film, showing how the wool industry is meeting this challenge, is an account of the work being done at various research centres throughout the Commonwealth, investigating and improving the production, processing, and use of wool.

results.title: New ways in farming
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
Illustrates modern trends in agriculture such as large-scale factory-style farming, with crops scientifically scheduled and cultivated. Discusses the farm co-operative; and shows how the traditionally independent farmer with the aid of new mechanised farm equipment, is able to make his farm an increasingly prosperous business.

results.title: New Wave: French Connection
results.brief_description:
A documentary account of a Punk/New Wave festival held in the Fourvieres roman theatre of Lyons in the summer of 1978. Fourvieres made its mark in the history of entertainement as a place where Christians were thrown to the lions. In 1978 only great expectations are shattered as ‘Marie et les garcons’ are booed off the stage. The concert showcases French exponents of the New Wave movement, such as Telephone, Bijou, Starshooters as well as Heavy Metal band Ganafoul and reggae outfit Cimarons, all working hard to prove that there is a world of peaceful harmony outside Disco. The documentary ends with that also familiar concert ritual: an ocean of empty beer cans being swept away.
Cast: Interviews by Jean-Francois Bizot.

results.title: New voices
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
In a world where the fortunes of one people crisscross with others, it is to be expected that the voices of Muslim countries will be raised on world issues. At the United Nations and other international gatherings, this film watches and listens to the new leaders of the Islamic world. What you see and hear has much meaning for you, and even more significance for the new African nations among whom Islam is a live and growing force.

results.title: New uses for Seaweed
results.brief_description: A brief account of the uses to which alginates, which are obtained from seaweed, are being put - from foodstuffs to toothpaste. A fine synthetic fibre, spun from the jelly is used in the manufacture of light-weight woollen materials.

results.title: New uses for coal waste
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
At the present level of coal usage a mountainous 15 million tonnes of waste is left behind every year after the coal is washed. Most of the waste is a coarse coal-bearing shale which is dumped in slag heaps. A program to reduce and utilise the waste from coal washeries has come up with far-reaching economic possibilities. The film looks at these possibilities.

results.title: New universities
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of the new universities program which seeks to extend facilities for university training in England. Taking the University of Sussex as the principal example, the film gives a picture of student life and activities in the fine modern buildings designed by Sir Basil Spence.

results.title: New twists on ocean currents
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Fibreglass buoys floating in the ocean are used to track the huge ocean currents off the coast of New South Wales. The buoys are proving highly reliable in supplying insights into the so-called East Australian currents.
